title: Combating Sexual Harassment in the Workplace: A Call to Action for All Members
author: Mondliwethu Moyo

blocks.text: Combating Sexual Harassment in the Workplace: A Call to Action for All Members

Sexual harassment in the workplace remains a serious issue that affects employees’ safety, dignity, and productivity. It can take many forms, from unwanted physical contact to inappropriate comments, gestures, or requests. No worker should ever feel unsafe or uncomfortable while performing their duties. As a union, it is our responsibility to ensure that every member knows their rights and has access to protection and support.
Sexual harassment includes any unwelcome behavior of a sexual nature that makes an employee feel intimidated, degraded, or humiliated. It can be:

items: Verbal: Inappropriate jokes, comments, or requests of a sexual nature.
Non-verbal: Leering, gestures, or displaying sexually explicit materials.
Physical: Unwanted touching, hugging, or other forms of physical contact.

blocks.text: Such behavior is not only morally unacceptable but also legally punishable under Zimbabwean labour laws and international labour standards.

Sexual harassment can have serious consequences for victims, including emotional distress, anxiety, reduced productivity, and even physical health issues. A workplace where harassment is ignored fosters fear and undermines teamwork, trust, and morale.
Our union is committed to creating a safe and respectful working environment. We urge all members to:

items: Know your rights: Every worker has the right to a harassment-free workplace.
Report incidents: Use official reporting channels within your institution or through the union.
Support colleagues: Stand together against harassment and ensure victims feel supported, not isolated.
Participate in training: Attend workshops on sexual harassment awareness and prevention.
Employers have a legal and moral duty to prevent sexual harassment. This includes:
Providing regular awareness and training programs.

blocks.text: Eliminating sexual harassment is not just a legal obligation—it is a moral imperative. Together, as a union, we can build workplaces where respect, dignity, and safety are non-negotiable. Let every member commit to speaking out, supporting victims, and holding perpetrators accountable.
If you or a colleague experiences harassment, report it immediately to your union representative. Together, we can ensure that no worker is left to suffer in silence.
